Amortization Table of Assumed 10 year loan (CAL)

Here is an assumption that the loan given would be 10 years long and constanly amortized to calculate interest and payments. Payments are subtracted from cash on the balance sheet, while interest is deducted from EBIT on the income statement.
This affects taxes, and net income.
Common Size Profit and Loss Statements

column13: In an expanding market, while the company is expanding there could be a thought that growth and scaling would reduce the costs, but this new policy would bring investments from abroad and domestically. The fierce competition would at the same time drive up their COGS hence the assumption that they will remain at the relative historical average

column1: Projections for 2013-17 based on your own assumptions

column13: As they grow, and are more lenient on credit terms in the short term, we can see a decently large increase in account receivables relative to sales, until it stabilizes.
Although sales are much higher now, inventory doesn't seem to be growing much due to the inventory turnover increase assumption.

Considering a projected 25% increase from 2012-2013, as well as the expected increase in Capex (net fixed assets) it is reasonable to expect some debt to be raised. Debt would be chosen over equity considering it is a much cheaper alternative (5% to 10%)
Normalized equity by subtracting current liabilities + debt from total assets

column1: Projections for 2013-17 based on your own assumptions

column13: As the industry gets hot, we can expect them to increase the inventory turnover, and gradually increase its days of sales in cash

Initial average collection period in 2013, should remain similar to the previous period as to capture more of the market the company can be expected to be more lenient on credit terms. The shock will gradually tame and as the company assimilates the growth, we can see it gradually come back down as they tighten abck up the credit terms.

Average collection period can be expected to be slightly higher than the previous years as the increase demand and size of orders can be expected to make suppliers more lenient on their terms, however it is a fine line.

Days of sales in inventory will see a sharp decrease as the inventory turnover increases with the followed demand. Plus with a shift in energy policy, and the gradual increase in efficiency from the company as they assimilate their growth, we can expect this turnover to stabilize and stay around 70.
FATO can be expected to slightly increase but not too much, as the company become mores efficient as it grows.

column12: Originally I would've assumed much larger growth in terms of sales for terminal year (at least 10%) as it is only 5 years after a large shift in policy benefitting the company, however the perpetual growth rate in this case cannot be larger than the wacc.
Therefore it is set to 5% in its last year, with 10% the previous year to mimic a stable decrease in growth but growth nonetheless.
